review.title: Parameterized Complexity of Problems in Coalitional Resource Games
review.abstract: Coalition formation is a key topic in multi-agent systems. Coalitions enable agents to achieve goals that they may not have been able to achieve on their own. Previous work has shown problems in coalitional games to be computationally hard. Wooldridge and Dunne (Artificial Intelligence 2006) studied the classical computational complexity of several natural decision problems in Coalitional Resource Games (CRG) - games in which each agent is endowed with a set of resources and coalitions can bring about a set of goals if they are collectively endowed with the necessary amount of resources. The input of coalitional resource games bundles together several elements, e.g., the agent set Ag, the goal set G, the resource set R, etc. Shrot, Aumann and Kraus (AAMAS 2009) examine coalition formation problems in the CRG model using the theory of Parameterized Complexity. Their refined analysis shows that not all parts of input act equal - some instances of the problem are indeed tractable while others still remain intractable.
histories: This is the full version of a paper that will appear in the proceedings of AAAI 2011
review.COMMENTS: This is the full version of a paper that will appear in the proceedings of AAAI 2011

metadata.title: Parameterized Complexity of Problems in Coalitional Resource Games

sections.text: ar Xiv: 110 5.07 07v1 [cs.AI] 3M ayWe answer an important question that Shrot, Aumann and Kraus have left open by showing that the SC problem (verifying whether a coalition is successful) is W [1] -hard when parameterized by the size of the coalition. Then, using a single topic of SC reduction, we can show that various problems related to resources, resource limits and resource conflicts parameterized by Wooldridge et al. 1. W [1] -hard or Co-W [1] -hard when parameterized by the size of the coalition are 2. para-NP-hard or co-para-NP-hard when parameterized by | R |.3. FPT when parameterized by either | G | or | Ag | + | R | R |.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 1.1 Coalitions
sections.text: In multi-agent systems (MAS), where each actor has limited resources, the formation of coalitions of actors is a very powerful tool [6]. Coalitions allow actors to achieve goals that they may not be able to achieve individually. Therefore, understanding and predicting the dynamics of coalitions, such as which coalitions are more advantageous and / or more likely, is a matter of considerable interest in multi-agent constellations. Unfortunately, a number of previous studies have shown that many of these problems are mathematically complex [7, 8]. Nevertheless, hardship results, as Garey and Johnson [4] noted, should only be the beginning of research. NP hardness merely indicates that a general solution to all cases of the problem most likely does not exist. Nevertheless, efficient solutions for important subclasses may well exist.

sections.heading: 1.2 Formal Model of Coalition Resource Games
sections.text: The framework we use to model coalitions is the CRG model introduced in [8], defined as follows. The model contains a non-empty, finite amount Ag = {a1,... a coalition, typically referred to by C, is simply a set of agents, i.e. a subset of Ag. The Grand Coalition is the set of all agents, Ag. There is also a finite set of goals. Each actor i. "Ag" is associated with a subset of goals. Agent i is satisfied if at least one member of Gi is reached, and dissatisfied otherwise. Achieving the goals requires the expenditure of resources drawn from the totality of resource types. Achieving different goals may require different quantities of each resource type. The quantity req (g, r) denotes the amount of resources r that is required to achieve the goal g. It is assumed that Req (r) is not a resource type. "Each" G "

sections.heading: 2 Problem Definitions and Previous Work
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 2.1 Problems Related to Coalition Formation
sections.text: Shrot et al. [5] considered the following four problems related to coalitions: 1. SUCCESS FUL COALITION (SC) instance: A CRG and a coalition C question: Is C successful? 2. SUCCESS FUL COALITION OF SIZE k (ESCK) instance: A CRG and a holistic k question: Is there a successful coalition of size exactly k? 3. SUCCESS FUL COALITION (MAXIMAL COALITION) instance: A CRG and a coalition C question: Is any proper translation of C not successful? 4. SUCCESS FUL COALITION (MAXS) instance: A CRG and a coalition C question: Is C successful and any proper translation of C unsuccessful? The results from Shrot et al. [5] are summarized in Figure G.

sections.heading: 3 Parameterized Complexity
sections.text: The definitions in this section are taken from [3] and [2]. The basic idea of parameterized complexity is to identify a specific part of the input as a parameter and to ask whether the problem allows an algorithm that is efficient in all but the parameter. In most cases, the parameter is simply one of the elements of the input (e.g. the size of the target), but it can actually be any calculable function of the input: Definition 3.1. Let's be a finite alphabet.1. Let there be parameterization of the input.

sections.heading: 4 Our Results & Techniques
sections.text: We consider problems related to resource boundaries and resource conflicts, which were found to be mathematically difficult in Wooldridge et al. ([8]), but not taken into account in Shrot et al. [5]. We also solve three open questions posed in Shrot et al., showing that the complexity of NR, SNR, CGRO, RPEGS, SCRB and CC problems are parameterized by the parameters FPT3. ESCK parameterized by | R | is para-NP-hardWe investigate the complexity of NR, RPEGS, SCRB and CC problems when parameterized by natural parameters.

sections.heading: 5 Problems Left Open in Shrot et al. [5]
sections.text: First, we show that SC is parameterized by C.

sections.heading: 6 Problems Related to Resources
sections.text: For a coalition C we remember the notation we use: succ (C) = {G ′ | G ′ G; G ′ 6 = / 0 and G ′ both met C and is feasible for them}. In this section we show hardening results for three different resource related problems.

sections.heading: 6.1 Necessary Resource (NR)
sections.text: The idea of a necessary resource is similar to that of a veto actor in the context of conventional coalition games. A resource is considered necessary when achieving a number of goals that are successful for the coalition would require non-zero use of that resource. So, if a necessary resource is scarce, then the actors who own the resource become important. We look at the NECESSARY REQUEL problem: If a coalition gives C and a resource r answer YES, if and only if req (G, r) > 0 for all G'succ (C). NR was shown to be a common NP full answer in Wooldridge et al. [8] We note that if C is not successful, then NR answers vacuum YES. We give a reduction from SC to NR.Lemma 6.1.

sections.heading: 6.2 Strictly Necessary Resource (SNR)
sections.text: The fact that a resource is necessary does not mean that it will be used. sections.heading: 7 Problems Related to Resource Bounds
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 7.1 R-Pareto Efficient Goal Set (RPEGS)
sections.text: We use the idea of Pareto efficiency to measure the optimality of a goal that we only achieve when we achieve it. In our model, we say that a goal that we have set ourselves is efficient even when no goal is set in succession (C), requiring at most as much of each resource and strictly less of any resource. Formally, we say that a goal that we have set is also a goal. (G) A goal is efficient. (G) A coalition C if and only when we achieve it. (C), r1 R: req (G). sections.heading: 8 Problems Related to Resource Conflicts
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 8.1 Conflicting Coalitions (CC)
sections.text: When two or more coalitions want to use a scarce resource, this leads to a conflict in the system. This problem is a classic problem in distributed and simultaneous systems. In our framework, we say that two objectives conflict if they are achievable individually within the resource commitment, but their union is not able to commit resources if and only if we have the interpretation that each resource quantity is limited for each resource r. We say that a goal G0 in terms of resource commitment b w.r.t. a given CRG (G1, G2, b) a given CRG (G1, G2, b) the fact that G1 and G2 are in conflict.

sections.heading: 11 Conclusions and Directions for Future Work
sections.text: We looked at some of the problems related to resource boundaries and resource conflicts that proved to be arithmetically difficult in [8] but not taken into account in [5]. We also solved 3 open questions posed in [5] by showing that the problem para-NP-hardWe also found an error in Theorem 3.2 which claimed that ESCK is parameterized by | G | is FPT. We give a counter-example to their algorithm and in fact show that the problem is para-NP-hard. Then we found an error in Theorem 3.2 of [5] which claimed that ESCK is parameterized by | G.

sections.text: We would like to thank Yuk Hei (Tom) Chan, Dana Nau and Kanthi Sarpatwar for helpful conversations.

metadata.abstractText: Coalition formation is a key topic in multi-agent systems. Coalitions enable agents to achieve goals that they may not have been able to achieve on their own. Previous work has shown problems in coalition games to be computationally hard. Wooldridge and Dunne (Artificial Intelligence 2006) studied the classical computational complexity of several natural decision problems in Coalitional Resource Games (CRG) games in which each agent is endowed with a set of resources and coalitions can bring about a set of goals if they are collectively endowed with the necessary amount of resources. The input of coalitional resource games bundles together several elements, e.g., the agent set Ag, the goal set G, the resource set R, etc. Shrot, Aumann and Kraus (AAMAS 2009) examine coalition formation problems in the CRG model using the theory of Parameterized Complexity. Their refined analysis shows that not all parts of input act equal some instances of the problem are indeed tractable while others still remain intractable. We answer an important question left open by Shrot, Aumann and Kraus by showing that the SC Problem (checking whether a Coalition is Successful) is W[1]-hard when parameterized by the size of the coalition. Then via a single theme of reduction from SC, we are able to show that various problems related to resources, resource bounds and resource conflicts introduced by Wooldridge et al are 1. W[1]-hard or co-W[1]-hard when parameterized by the size of the coalition. 2. para-NP-hard or co-para-NP-hard when parameterized by |R|. 3. FPT when parameterized by either |G| or |Ag|+ |R|. ∗Supported in part by Google Faculty Research Award, ONR Young Investigator Award and NSF CAREER award. †Department of Computer Science , University of Maryland at College Park, USA, email: rchitnis@cs.umd.edu ‡Department of Computer Science , University of Maryland at College Park, USA. email: hajiagha@cs.umd.edu §Department of Computer Science , University of Maryland at College Park, USA. email: vliaghat@cs.umd.edu
